content.text: Connect the crocodile clip near end \(\mathbf{X}\) of the resistance wire
* Switch on
Adjust the position of the crocodile clip until the potential difference \(V\) across terminals \(\mathbf{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\) is 2.0V
* Record, in Table 1.1, the value of the current \(I\) shown on the ammeter
* Move the crocodile clip and record values of \(I\) for \(V = 1.8 \text{V}, 1.6 \text{V}, 1.4 \text{V}\) and \(1.2 \text{V}\)
* Switch off
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (y-axis) against \(I / A\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(M\) of the graph
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The gradient \(M\) is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the power supply
Write down the resistance \(R\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Suggest one practical reason why the crocodile clip should not be connected to very short lengths of resistance wire in order to obtain smaller potential differences
In this type of experiment, it is possible to change the potential difference by using a variable resistor rather than using different lengths of a resistance wire
In the space, draw the standard circuit symbol for a variable resistor
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a power supply. The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Measure the weight \(W_{1}\) of the piece of modelling clay, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Pour approximately \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder
Record the volume \(V_{1}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder
Describe briefly how a measuring cylinder is read to obtain an accurate value for the volume of water. You may draw a diagram
Lower the piece of modelling clay into the water as shown in Fig. 2.2
• Record the new reading \(W_{2}\) of the forcemeter
• Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the measuring cylinder, with the piece of modelling clay in the water
• Remove the modelling clay from the measuring cylinder
• **Do not empty the measuring cylinder.**
Calculate a value \(\rho_{1}\) for the density of water, using your readings from **(a)**, **(b)** and **(c)** and the equation
where \(k = 100 \text{g / N}\)
Measure the mass \(m_{1}\) of the measuring cylinder, still containing the volume \(V_{1}\) of water. Use the balance provided
• Empty the measuring cylinder
• Measure the mass \(m_{2}\) of the empty measuring cylinder
Calculate a second value \(\rho_{2}\) for the density of water, using your readings from **(b)** and **(e)** and the equation
Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in either **Method 1** or **Method 2**, even when they are carried out carefully
Explain how an improvement might be made to reduce this inaccuracy
suggestion
explanation of improvement
In this experiment, you will determine the density of water by two methods
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 2.1 and 2.2
Fig. 2.2
Place the block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners ABCD, as indicated in Fig. 3.1
• Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet
• Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{L}\), \(1\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Label the other end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{N}\)
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{FL}\), \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta = 30^{\circ}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in **(a)**
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{FL}\), a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\)

• View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in position \(\mathbf{X}\) in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), all appear exactly one behind the other
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\)
• Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet
Draw a line joining \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Extend this line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\)
Draw a line through \(\mathbf{G}\), at \(90^{\circ}\) to \(\mathbf{CD}\). Extend this line until it crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\)
Extend line \(\mathbf{FL}\) until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Label the point at which it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{K}\)
Join points \(\mathbf{L}\) and \(\mathbf{G}\) with a straight line
Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{LG}\)
Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{LK}\)
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in **(a)**
• Replace the two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line FL
• Place the mirror against side \(\mathbf{CD}\), with the reflecting surface towards the block

• View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in position \(\mathbf{Y}\) in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{5}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{6}\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{5}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{6}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), all appear exactly one behind the other
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{5}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{6}\)
• Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet
Draw a line joining \(\mathsf{P}_{5}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{6}\). Extend this line until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{M}\)
Label the other end of the line with the letter \(\mathbf{R}\)
Measure the angle \(\alpha\), where \(\alpha\) is the smaller angle between lines \(\mathbf{RM}\) and \(\mathbf{GH}\)
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) and angle \(\theta\), measured in part **(a)**, should be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer with reference to your results
statement
justification
Suggest why different students, all carrying out this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block
You will determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
Plan an experiment to investigate how increasing the number of layers of insulation affects the rate of cooling of hot water in a beaker
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
Write a plan for the experiment, including:
· the apparatus needed
· what you would measure
· the variables you would keep the same to ensure the comparison is a fair test
· instructions for carrying out the experiment
· how you would present your results
· how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
